author: Staff Reporter
text:
“During one of the most difficult times like the recent floods, people here proved how resilient they were,” Roy Kho, Consul General of Consulate General of the Republic of Singapore, said here on Sunday.

Speaking at the inauguration of the 10{+t}{+h}dance festival at the Music Academy, Mr. Kho said the floods, in a way, showed how compassionate and generous people of the city were and how people came forward, contributed and helped.

He said India might be often associated with festivals but this was not just religious alone, it also included performing arts, literature, culture, food and many more. “In December and January, Chennai is the focal point of South Indian classical art. The city comes alive with music and dance, reviving the glorious past of its spiritual and aesthetic values,” he added.

At the festival, dancer Alarmel Valli was conferred an award and the title ‘Natya Kala Acharya.’ She recollected the first time she performed at the Music Academy when she was 15. “It seems as if it was only yesterday that I danced here in this auditorium. I vividly remember my guru telling me: ‘be careful while you dance, it is the Music Academy.’ I am honoured by the award,” she said. Gutti Vasu Memorial Prize for Best Dancers was shared by Meera Sreenarayanan and Sudharma Vaidyanathan and the second prize went to R. Gayathri.

The Dance Guru awards went to Nirmala Nagaraj and A. Lakshmananswamy and the HCL Concert Series Best Dancer award was given to Christopher Gurusamy.

N. Murali, president of the Music Academy also spoke during the occasion.

Gutti Vasu Memorial Prize for best dancers was shared by Meera and Sudharma
title: Alarmel Valli conferred Natya Kala Acharya title
